Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of predictability in reference production: Effects of semantic role, utterance planning, and audience design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Among the core cognitive abilities that facilitates human communication is the ability to exploit various types of referring expressions--names, descriptions, and pronouns--to identify the objects, entities, and concepts that serve as predicate arguments in sentences. Communicative success depends heavily on how speakers choose among the full range of potential referring expressions to single out a specific predicate argument.

People are good at tracking the predictability of events in the world. Such predictability has strong effects on language use. For example, speakers tend to use shorter and simpler linguistic forms when information is predictable, such as pronouns (he/she) instead of longer expressions (Sue, the woman), and more acoustically reduced pronunciations instead of longer/emphatic ones. This study examines one domain where this effect is debated: semantic role predictability. If a speaker reports an event like "Ann passed Sue the ball," some events are relatively more likely continuations, e.g. "... and Sue shot a basket." This stems from the semantic role of Sue: she was the recipient of the ball, and therefore might be expected to do something with it. Yet researchers disagree whether this type of predictability matters for pronoun production. And despite extensive evidence that acoustic reduction is influenced by predictability in general, no one has looked at how acoustic reduction is affected by semantic role predictability.

In this NSF-funded project, Dr. Jennifer Arnold and her students aim to solve the puzzle of semantic role predictability effects on reference form. They use new experimental methods that aim to mimic the characteristics of natural language production, and corpus analysis to measure semantic role predictability from real language use. They take a comprehensive approach, examining both pronoun use and acoustic reduction. Semantic-role predictability will be examined against the backdrop of other well-known effects, like syntactic predictability. Eye-tracking and timing analyses will provide evidence about the cognitive mechanisms of reference production.

This study will shed light on fundamental questions about how people track information in the world and incorporate it into daily behaviors like language. It will provide a framework for training both graduate and undergraduate students, and will provide information necessary for developing a mechanistic model of reference production

POR.DRECONTENT:
When people speak, their interlocutors often anticipate what will be said next. One way comprehenders might predict is by anticipating who or what will be mentioned next. This predictability is known to facilitate understanding, but researchers disagree about whether speakers choose different words when the referent is predictable. Sometimes speakers use less-specific forms for predictable information, like pronouns (he, she) or shorter pronunciations. However, many researchers argue that speakers ignore predictability when deciding whether to use a pronoun.

We examined two types of context, both of which have been linked with predictability:

1)    Transfer verbs

  1. Valerie gave the book to Sandy.
  2. Sandy got the book from Valerie.

2)    Implicit Causality verbs

  1. Elyce amazed Kathryn.
  2. Kathryn admired Elyce.

When listeners hear a sentence about a transfer event, they tend to expect the speaker to continue talking about the goal (Sandy) which makes this referent predictable. Likewise, implicit causality verbs induce an expectation that the speaker will continue talking about the likely cause (Elyce). The question behind this project is whether talking about the expected referent will lead speakers to use pronouns more than explicit expressions like names (Elyce, Kathryn) or descriptions (the student, the woman). Previous work in this area led to conflicting results, where work with transfer verbs found that speakers use pronouns more for goals, but work with implicit causality verbs found no such effect. To solve this puzzle, we developed new methods so we could test language production in more natural contexts. We also tested whether speakers used shorter pronunciations to refer to predictable roles, and examined the production mechanisms behind these choices.

Findings from this study definitively established that following transfer events, reference to the goal character encourages speakers to use pronouns, or even drop the pronoun altogether, compared to reference to source character. This is a major advancement, and challenges models that account for pronoun production purely in terms of grammatical function. We also provided the first information that speakers use shorter pronunciations for goal roles, but that this effect is explained by the tendency for goal continuations to be produced more quickly and fluently.

On the other hand, the predictability of implicit causes had a less systematic effect on pronoun production. Unlike previous studies, we did find that implicit causality verbs affected pronoun use, but not in consistent ways. We also discovered that implicit causality verbs and transfer verbs are different in the degree to which they make referents predictable. We examined how speakers use these verbs in a corpus of naturally occurring language, and found that while goals are frequently referred to, implicit causes are not. In addition, goals tend to have central roles in discourses more than implicit causes.

We also used eyetracking to establish two important findings about how utterance planning relates to reference production. First, the use of pronouns and zeros was linked to early planning: when speakers looked at the target panel while hearing the context sentence, they were more likely to use pronouns/zeros. This is an important outcome, because little previous work has established the timecourse of pronoun selection. However, thematic roles were unrelated to early planning, and instead affected looks to the target panel immediately before the response. This demonstrates that the goal bias is not a side-effect of planning.

This project also yielded several key outcomes that extended the project in natural ways. First, we found that participants are surprisingly variable in their production of reference form, even within the same task and discourse context. We used eyetracking to link this variation to the timecourse of planning. Second, we replicated the goal bias for pronoun use in Spanish, which has a more complex referential system. In Spanish speakers can choose between names/descriptions; pro-drop, and explicit pronouns (el, ella). We found that the goal bias specifically affected the use of overt pronouns. This finding challenges existing models of reference in pro-drop languages.

This project supported the training of 5 graduate students and 22 undergraduate students, thus contributing to STEM education. Two new experimental paradigms were developed, and the visual and linguistic stimuli have been made publicly available at https://jaapstimuli.web.unc.edu/.
